{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3523009,"name":"","username":"Mateo","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/f4b2a3/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-11T03:25:07.883Z","cooked":"

3324 here again, not Mateo this time though, just posting on his account. As you may have noticed from our many problem threads, we have been having significant issues with our MK4i swerve (neos), using thrifty encoders. Our current version of the code can be found at: GitHub - Mateo-Johnson/swerg, and it seems to have fixed many of the issues mentioned before, but we still seem to have some issues with some sort of drift in our analog encoders. Every time we deploy code we are noticing a slight drift, small but noticeable enough that over around three deploys, we are ~20 degrees off. Our solution to this currently is to asynchronously reset our analog offsets every time the rio boots up, but we are open to other solutions as well! In addition, one of our modules does not seem to want to accept that it must face forward! We’ll update tomorrow with code testing and progress!

we still seem to have some issues with some sort of drift in our analog encoders. Every time we deploy code we are noticing a slight drift, small but noticeable enough that over around three deploys, we are ~20 degrees off. Our solution to this currently is to asynchronously reset our analog offsets every time the rio boots up, but we are open to other solutions as well! In addition, one of our modules does not se

Any chance your magnets are not glued in properly? We didnt use enough green locktite on them last year and had one drift over time.

This is definitely an issue. The module is trying to reach an angle and its not getting there. Have you tried tuning this PID loop?

github.com

Mateo-Johnson/swerg/blob/aa8fe5d313c611fb73e7f6990f99979cc798601a/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/MAXSwerveModule.java#L56C6-L57C1

    2.
